Description: Hollow terracotta standing beneficent demon, with arms held up in blessing and protection. She is naked and stands on a small plinth. The details are very indistinct; wide wreath round head, summary detail at rear. The right arm is lost and top of the wreath broken away. Two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt, with a red-brown surface and a brown core. Overall white dressing. Roughly applied pink paint details, below breasts and across plinth.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: British School of Archaeology in Egypt. From Shurafa, the same source as registration no. 1912,1019.15. Late Roman, fifth century AD? Comparanda: Close: Bruyère 1966: 104, fig. 4:1; Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, E.170.1912, from Shurafa; Petrie Museum uc48400. Near: Bayer-Niemeier 1988: no. 259, dated second third of fourth century AD; Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, E.169.1912, from Shurafa, and E.P.221, probably from Shurafa. Not unlike: Bresciani 1968: pls B:4 and lix:36, with exaggerated waist and hips, from Narmuthis, dated fourth to sixth century AD.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3123)
Petrie at al 1915 / Heliopolis, Kafr Ammar and Shurafa (p. 44)
Condition: incomplete - left arm and top of the head lost
Acquisition name: Donated by: British School of Archaeology, Egypt
